September 3, 2006: Fiction
JUDGE & JURY, by James Patterson and Andrew Gross. (Little, Brown, $27.99.)
An aspiring actress and an F.B.I. agent join forces against a powerful mobster.
RICOCHET, by Sandra Brown. (Simon & Schuster, $25.95.) A detective is
attracted to a judge's wife who he also suspects is not telling the truth about a fatal
shooting.
INTO THE STORM, by Suzanne Brockmann. (Ballantine, $21.95.) A night of
passion raises the temperature between a member of the Navy Seals and a former
cop who must work together to track a serial killer in a remote corner of New
Hampshire.
ANGELS FALL, by Nora Roberts. (Putnam, $25.95.) When a chef from Boston,
now living in Wyoming, witnesses a murder, the locals won't believe her.
THE MESSENGER, by Daniel Silva. (Putnam, $25.95.) Gabriel Allon, an art
restorer and an occasional spy for the Israeli secret service, uncovers an Al Qaeda
plot against the Vatican.
SPECIAL TOPICS IN CALAMITY PHYSICS, by Marisha Pessi (Viking, $25.95.) A
motherless teenager who has spent much of her life on the road with her father
joins a circle of students who are enchanted with a teacher bearing a tragic secret.
THE RUINS, by Scott Smith. (Knopf, $24.95.) Two young American couples on
vacaton in the Yucatán confront a horrible menace.
CAN'T WAIT TO GET TO HEAVEN, by Fannie Flagg. (Random House, $29.95.) A
return to Elmwood Springs, Mo., the setting of Flagg's novel "Standing in the
Rainbow."
TRIPTYCH, by Karin Slaughter. (Delacorte, $25.) In the hunt for a killer with a
nasty signature, a veteran Atlanta detective in a troubled marriage is teamed with a
vice cop who happens to be his ex-lover.
PHANTOM, by Terry Goodkind. (Tor/Tom Doherty, $29.95.) The 11th volume of
the "Sword of Truth" fantasy series.
WATER FOR ELEPHANTS, by Sara Gruen (Algonquin, $24.95.) A young man —
and an elephant — save a Depression-era circus.
CRISIS, by Robin Cook. (Putnam, $25.95.) There are shocking revelations at a
medical malpractice trial.
TWELVE SHARP, by Janet Evanovich. (St. Martin's, $26.95.) The bounty hunter
Stephanie Plum must find a killer and rescue a kidnapped child.
SPY, by Ted Bell. (Atria, $25.95.) The British Secret Service agent Alex Hawke
September 3, 2006
Non-Fiction
MARLEY & ME, by John Grogan. (Morrow, $21.95.) A newspaper columnist and
his wife learn some life lessons from their neurotic dog.
FIASCO, by Thomas E. Ricks. (The Penguin Press, $27.95.) How the Bush
administration's and the military's failure to understand the developing Iraqi
insurgency contributed to its further growth.
I FEEL BAD ABOUT MY NECK, by Nora Ephron. (Knopf, $19.95.) A witty look at
aging from a novelist and screenwriter ("When Harry Met Sally").
THE WORLD IS FLAT, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.50;
updated and expanded edition, $30.) A columnist for The New York Times
analyzes 21st-century economics and foreign policy.
THE LOOMING TOWER, by Lawrence Wright. (Knopf, $27.95.) The road to 9/11
as seen through the lives of terrorists planners and the F.B.I. counterterrorism
chief.
FREAKONOMICS, by Steven D. Levitt and Stephen J. Dubner. (Morrow, $25.95.)
A maverick scholar applies economic thinking to everything from sumo wrestlers
who cheat to legalized abortion and the falling crime rate.
DISPATCHES FROM THE EDGE, by Anderson Cooper. (HarperCollins, $24.95.)
The CNN correspondent describes a year of covering the tsunami in Sri Lanka, the
war in Iraq and Hurricane Katrina.
MAYFLOWER, by Nathaniel Philbrick. (Viking, $29.95.) How America began, from
the author of "In the Heart of the Sea."
OVERCOMING LIFE'S DISAPPOINTMENTS, by Harold S. Kushner. (Knopf,
$21.95.) The author of "When Bad Things Happen to Good People" finds lessons
for living in the faith and resilience of Moses.
GODLESS, by Ann Coulter. (Crown Forum, $27.95.) The columnist argues that
liberalism is a religion with sacraments, a creation myth and a clergy.
BLINK, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown, $29.95.)The author of "The Tipping
Point" explores the importance of hunch and instinct to the workings of the mind.
THE LANGUAGE OF GOD, by Francis S. Collins. (Free Press, $26.) The head of
the Human Genome Project argues that faith in God and faith in science can
coexist.
THE ONE PERCENT DOCTRINE, by Ron Suskind. (Simon & Schuster, $27.) An
investigation of the Bush administration's strategic thinking and of the role of
ideology and personality in the decision to go to war.
